title.narrative: Improving health, water and sanitation conditions for conflict affected populations in Darfur

description.narrative: As a result of population movement, many different groups of people live in Darfur, including internally displaced persons, returnees and refugees from neighbouring countries. There is a lack of access to primary healthcare and adequate water and sanitation facilities, which makes these communities even more vulnerable. By the end of 2014, there were about 3.7 million vulnerable people living in the greater Darfur region, of which approximately 2.5 million people are displaced within their own country.
The project is implemented in West (Sirba and Habila localities) and Central (Mukjar locality) Darfur states

The purpose of this project is to ensure that vulnerable communities in Darfur, both local people and people who are displaced in their own country, have access to health, water and sanitation facilities.
As it is an emergency project there will be no baseline.
We work with vulnerable communities in Darfur, including internally displaced persons, people returning to Darfur after having fled the conflict previously, and people who are local to the area.

With regard to health services, the priorities are to support the operations of primary health centres in areas where there are many internally displaced persons. The other main priorities of the project are to maintain water, sanitation and hygiene services in camps for internally displaced persons, but also in areas where local people live, to prevent disease outbreaks.

comment.narrative: 10 staff from West and Central Darfur attended HR training at Khartoum facilitated by RedR in December 2017. The operation manager and WASH Engineer will be attending a 2 weeks HR training by AMREF in Nairobi in March 2018 and HR coordinator at SRCS HQ attended HR training in Turkey

10 staff from West and Central Darfur attended HR training at Khartoum facilitated by RedR in December 2017. The operation manager and WASH Engineer will be attending a 2 weeks HR training by AMREF in Nairobi in March 2018 and HR coordinator at SRCS HQ attended HR training in Turkey

10 staff partipciated in a two days (18 and 19th Feb 2018) M and E workshop held at Khartoum facilitated by PMER HQ team. This trainig was in adition to an earlier training done by the Project delegate to the 3 key staff on basic M and E

8 staffs are on the payroll since October 2016 working in the clinics of Al Royadh and Kirinding in Geniena locality. The SMOH has seconded further 10 staff (2 medical assistants, 2 nurses, 2 lab assistants, 2 midwives, and 2 dispensers to the clinic of Korgy and Abudahiya. Community has provided 2 security guards.

title.narrative: Number of latrines constructed or rehabilitated

comment.narrative: Construction of 2 toilet pits with 5 stances ongoing in Mukjar (market and hospital). In Habila and Sirba, 1 toilet each with 4 stances ongoing. Completion project in June.
Construction of 2 toilet pits with 5 stances ongoing in Mukjar (market and hospital). In Habila and Sirba, 1 toilet each with 4 stances ongoing. Completion project in June.

title.narrative: Dissemination of IEC materials on reproductive health

comment.narrative: During the SMOH supported vaccination campaigns, 954 pieces of IEC materials were distributed with specific messages on ANC, HIV/AIDS and hygiene practices. The messages were adapted from UNICEF/MOH models on breastfeeding, reproductive health services utilization.

title.narrative: # and Type of IEC materials on reproductive health produced

comment.narrative: a total of 954 pieces of IEC were distributed (344 on RH, 323 on HIV/AIDS and 278 on Hygiene were designed and produced

title.narrative: Conduct hygiene promotion sessions using the PHAST approach

comment.narrative: 3 trainings done reaching to 30 facilitators in the three localities. However, during routine monitoring, facilitators seems to have missed the methodology. A re-training is planned beginning March 201

In Mukjar, 40 volunteers (23 males/17 femalee) together with the community conducted cleaning up campaign in collaboration with UNAMID in Mukjar market, hospital and in IDP camp settlement. Four 10 ton lorry rubbish was collected and disposed. Total of 5 campaigns conducted in Mukjar. In Habila and Sirbir – 40 volunteers were joined by more than 300 participants in the cleaning campaigns that involved cutting grass, drainage clearance and burning rubbish.

title.narrative: # of water committee (WC) meetings in the three localities

comment.narrative: The WUCs in the three localities of Mukjar, Habila and Sirba have routine meetings on every months. The committees have so far had 12 meetings across the localities. WUC are more active in the rural than urban. Those in urban Habila, Sirba and Mukjar are demanding incentives and other support to participate in meetings

title.narrative: Health - Knowledge on relevant health topics, health promotion, disease prevention and treatment

comment.narrative: 467 men, 5913 women and 5285 young persons were reached with reproductive health messaging, particularly the importance of attending antenatal clinic in 129 sessions

A total of 9 health and hygiene promotion campaigns were held in Mukjar, Sirba and Habila reaching to 1,339 men, 4,678 women and 4,365 young persons with messages on Malaria and AWD

International Emergency Health Kit (IEHK) procured by NLRC at the Hague were delivered in January. The average utilization rate for Al Riyadha and Kriding PHCs in Geneina was 0.2 and 0.5 respectively. The clinic of Abudahiya and Korgy are only operational effective January 18.
